Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the research process for writing an economics paper from start to finish.

I really learned how to do independent econometric research: how to find and clean data sets, how to code variables, how to run statistical models, how to read and process related academic literature, how to present findings in words, figures, and tables, etc.   It was an incredibly useful exercise in just about every way imaginable.
Picking a research question, data searching, data cleaning and analysis, statistical methods, research methods and literature review, data visualisation. i also learnt a lot about my topic.
Fantastic, in-depth experience of an economics topic of your choosing.
More practice with economics research, the methods in economic research, etc.
Data analysis, R coding, outputting charts and graphs, research

I was able to use and develop my econometrics skills learned from my major classes to conduct independent research. I learned specific subject-matter related to the research. I feel very comfortable with the main literature on the topic, and finding a economic question to study that has not yet been heavily worked in the professional literature was one main skills that I was able to learn while writing the thesis.

I learned about how to conduct independent research: how to create a research question, how to gather and clean data in R, how to create visualizations, how to run complicated regressions and create my own models, how to communicate my research in a way appropriate with the academy, how to problem solve, etc. I learned specifically about the economics of forestry.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More structure around deadlines, more specifications about how it's graded (in a consistent way across advisors).
There is a lot of support available if you need it, whether it's help with coding, choosing a topic, writing, or really anything! The course is very open-ended.

Econ 492 isn't really a "course" in the traditional sense, so I don't think I could offer any suggestions as to how it could be improved.  The experience you get from it depends entirely on what you, as an individual, put into it.
Very rewarding experience but also very advisor dependent. I just wish there were more in-between deadlines.
I appreciate all the resources available for this course. I see no obvious weaknesses.
I did not utilize the resources from this course so I cannot speak intelligently about its strengths or weaknesses.
The course was just independent research with help from my Thesis Advisor.
Much of this course is based on the advisor you have. I feel very lucky to have Professor Robert Mendelsohn who was very interested and available.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found that the course adapted really well to the online format since it's mostly self-led (besides meetings with our advisors).
I don't think any real adjustments needed to be made during the pandemic---students generally spend all of their time in Econ 492 working independently.
I appreciate that lectures were recorded but not mandatory.
Not very much changed with COVID -- the main difference was meeting with my advisor on Zoom rather than in person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely if you want to gain research experience and explore an interesting question in economics!
Yes.  It is extremely challenging to do a two-semester thesis in economics, but is also incredibly rewarding and useful.
Yes! Econ research is great, and everyone in the major should do it!
Write a thesis if you want to! Not sure of the long-term benefits just yet, but it was cool.

Yes, the Economics thesis is necessary for Distinction in the Major, and it feels good to have a Capstone project from my time as an undergraduate student at Yale University. Tt demonstrates rigor in your intellectual pursuits, and the challenge is truly rewarded with a sense of achievement.
I would recommend this to any student who really loves ECON or who is considering a PhD. It is pretty intense so keep that in mind.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: self taught
Self-led with weekly emails and office hours
I mostly worked on my research independently, occasionally meeting with my advisor over Zoom to get his (invaluable) advice.
The instructor held office hours
Meetings with Advisor
Independent senior research project.
one on one meeting with advisor
None
Independent research with Advisor

This was an independent study. I met with my advisor (Professor Robert Mendelsohn) on Zoom once a week to provide updates on my progress. I also used the Statlab and enlisted in support from Vitor, the TF.
